note_text:
Admission Date:  [**2200-6-10**]              Discharge Date:   [**2200-6-16**]

Date of Birth:  [**2131-1-1**]             Sex:   F

Allergies:
Penicillins

Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 3276**]
Chief Complaint:
GI bleeding, anemia, new brain mets

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none


History of Present Illness:
69 yo female with SCLC, h/o embolic CVA on coumadin, admitted to
MICU [**6-10**] for melena in setting of supratherapeutic INR;
transferred to OMED with probable brain mets, ? whole brain
radiation.
Pt was initally referred to [**Hospital1 2177**] ED by her PCP for INR = 11. In
ED, she was found to have guaiac + black stool with HCT =19. She
received FFP,PRBC and Vit K. She was transferred to [**Hospital1 18**] ED for
further evaluation after a head CT revealed "diffuse lesions."
On arrival she was HD stable, but had one episode of frank
melena. She was transfused with 4 FFP, 2 PRBC, and Proplex
(factor 9) and admitted to the MICU for observation. She
remained HD stable overnight without further melena. A repeat
non-contrast head CT was done, which was c/w new metastatic
lesions. Today neurosurgery and radiation oncology both
recommended MRI to further characterize lesions give h/o
multiple emboli.
Currently she has no complaints. States no f/c/cough/sob/chest
pain/abd pain/n/v/dysuria.


Past Medical History:
1.  Small cell lung CA diagnosed [**10-28**] during admission for
cough/fatigue/wt loss. Mets to Finished 3 cycles of etoposide
and cisplatin, now wants no more treatment.
2.  DM II since '[**84**]
3.  PVD
4.  HTN
5.  Anemia
6.  GERD
7.  h/o guaiac + black stool: colonoscopy [**12-28**] with hemorrhagic
ulcers in cecum c/w ischemia vs emoli, AVM, internal.
hemorrhoids. EGD [**12-28**] wnl.
8. CVA [**12-28**] - multiple emboli in bilateral occipital lobes, the
right basal ganglia and both cerebellar hemispheres
9. TTE [**12-28**] - EF >60, 1+MR, moderate pulmonary htn
10. depression
11. tonsillectomy


Social History:
-70 pack year history of smoking tobacco, quit [**10-28**]
-Lives with son and nephew. [**Name (NI) **] home hospice. Does ambulate with
cane.
-Daughter is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 100304**]


Family History:
1.  Father - long time smoker with lung CA
2.  Mother - died of stomach CA


Physical Exam:
PE: 97.9, 140/70, 98, 140/70, 97% RA
gen: well appearing, pleasant, responds to questions
appropriately
heent: mmm, OC clear, neck supple
lungs: scattered rhonchi with wheeze, poor air movement
throughout
cv: rrr, no m
abd: soft, thin, nt
ext: w/wp, no edema
neuro: A+O x 3, CN II - XII intact, motor strength symmetric [**5-29**]
all extremities, no Babinski, poor finger to nose/rapid
alternating movement

Pertinent Results:
CT HEAD WITHOUT IV CONTRAST: No intracranial hemorrhage is
identified. Within the right and left cerebellar hemispheres,
there are two foci of increased density, which are well
circumscribed, and likely represent metastatic foci. These
measure approximately 12 mm on the right and 10 mm within the
left cerebellar hemisphere. Additionally, there is a third
lesion within the posterior aspect of the right temporal lobe,
which measures approximately 12 mm. This lesion demonstrates
surrounding decreased attenuation, consistent with edema. The
ventricles are symmetric, and there is no shift of normally
midline structures. Within the occipital lobes bilaterally,
there is focal encephalomalacia from prior infarct. The
[**Doctor Last Name 352**]-white matter differentiation is preserved. The soft tissue
and osseous structures are normal. No lytic or sclerotic lesions
are identified within the visualized osseous structures.
IMPRESSION: Three new foci are seen within the cerebellar
hemispheres and the posterior aspect of the right temporal lobe.
These are consistent with new metastatic foci, which were not
previously seen on the prior study. No intracranial hemorrhage
is identified. Results were discussed with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 714**]
[**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] at 11:50 a.m. on [**2200-6-11**].

Admission labs:

POTASSIUM-4.7 CHLORIDE-104 TOTAL CO2-27 ANION GAP-13

MCV-95 MCH-32.1* MCHC-33.9 RDW-16.0*
[**2200-6-10**] 09:45PM   NEUTS-80* BANDS-1 LYMPHS-12* MONOS-5 EOS-2
BASOS-0 ATYPS-0 METAS-0 MYELOS-0

Brief Hospital Course:
A/P: 69 yo female with small cell lung ca, h/o embolic CVA,
admitted with melena in setting of supratherapeutic INR, as well
as new brain metastases

1. New brain lesions

She has a history of metastatic small cell lung cancer, and was
found
on CT to have potential new brain metastases. This was confirmed
by MRI,
which demonstrated 4 brain metastases with edema, but no mass
effect.
She was started on treatment dose of decadron. Radiation
Oncology was consulted,
but ultimately, the patient decided against any further
treatment including brain
irradiation. Her goals of care and code status were discussed
during this admission, and - in light of this evidence of her
further progressed disease - she and her family decided together
that she is DNR/DNI, and that she wants no further
invasive/aggressive treatment. Specifically, no further
chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or any other aggressive
treatment. She will be d/c to rehab for further care.

2. GIB

She has a history of GI bleeding in the setting of cecal ulcers
and AVM.
She presented with significant GI bleeding with Hct of 19 in the
context
of supratherapeutic INR of 11. She was managed in the ICU with
Vit K, FFP,
and supportive blood transfusions. She thereafter remained
hemodynamically stable,
had no further GI bleeding, and her Hct remained stable.

The risks of recurrent embolic stroke were outweighed by the
benefit of
holding her coumadin in the setting of active GI bleeding and
new hemorrhagic
brain metastases. Her INR trended down from 11 to 1.2 after
holding coumadin,
giving vit K and FFP.  She will have no further anticoagulation.

3. SCLCA
No plan for further chemotherapy/radiation as above.

4. DM2
ISS in house



Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care

Facility:
[**Hospital3 2558**] - [**Location (un) **]

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Advanced stage Small Cell lung cancer
2. Brain metastases - on decadron; no XRT
3. GI bleeding, resolved
4. history of cecal ulcers, avm
5. DM 2
6. History of embolic stroke - no further anticoagulation
secondary to brain metastases and GI bleeding


Discharge Condition:
fair

Discharge Instructions:
Call your doctor for any rectal bleeding/blood in stool, or
any new weakness, numbness, difficutly speaking or swallowing,
or
any other concerns.

Followup Instructions:
1. Call Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3274**] and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 16212**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] for
follow up in clinic in the next two weeks
